channel.title: Papers I Like (PRPL Lab, Tom Silver)

item.title: Control-Limited Differential Dynamic Programming
item.description: This paper has an extremely clear and concise overview of trajectory optimization for robotics, especially DDP.
item.author: Tassa et al., ICRA 2014

item.title: Impossibly Good Experts and How to Follow Them
item.description: A very well written paper that will be especially interesting if you're using teacher-student training in your work.
item.author: Walsman et al., ICLR 2023

item.title: Gaussian Process Implicit Surfaces for Shape Estimation and Grasping
item.description: Useful if you're thinking about implicit representations for manipulation. Also +1 for uncertainty quantification.
item.author: Dragiev et al., ICRA 2011

item.title: Simple Random Search of Static Linear Policies is Competitive for RL
item.description: "Simple baselines should be established before moving forward to more complex [ones]." Generally agree!
item.author: Mania et al., NeurIPS 2018

item.title: A Tour of Reinforcement Learning: The View from Continuous Control
item.description: Pairs well with the PaperILiked last week -- another good bridge between RL and control theory.
item.author: Recht, 2018

item.title: Model Predictive Control and Reinforcement Learning: A Unified Framework Based on Dynamic Programming
item.description: If you know 1 of {RL, controls} and want to understand the other, this is a good starting point.
item.author: Bertsekas, 2024

item.title: The Structure of Scientific Revolutions
item.description: Zooming way, way out and thinking about what we're all doing here. (I'll get back to robots & AI next week.)
item.author: Kuhn, 1962

item.title: Learning Reusable Manipulation Strategies
item.description: This paper is my favorite recent account of how robots can learn & dramatically generalize "tricks" or "mechanisms" from very little data.
item.author: Mao et al., CoRL 2023

item.title: The Child as Hacker
item.description: I like the emphasis not only on code & program synthesis, but also on intrinsic motivation to guide open-ended learning.
item.author: Rule et al., Trends in CogSci 2020

item.title: Is More Autonomy Always Better?
item.description: Across AI+robotics, we should ask: How can give users more autonomy *options*? ( eq How can we maximize autonomy?)
item.author: Bhattacharjee et al., HRI 2020

item.title: Adapting Robot Behavior to User Preferences in Assistive Scenarios
item.description: Learning to personalize physically assistive robots with hierarchical planning in the mix!
item.author: Camprodon, PhD Thesis 2020

item.title: Sampling-Based Methods for Motion Planning with Constraints
item.description: Our field needs more surveys like this -- helpful & accessible. See also Berenson's "Obeying Constraints During Motion Planning."
item.author: Kingston et al., ARCRAS 2018

item.title: 'Just In Time' Representations for Mental Simulation in Intuitive Physics
item.description: Inspiring for those of us who are trying to get robots to generate just-in-time abstractions for planning & reasoning.
item.author: Chen et al., CogSci 2023

item.title: ShapeCoder: Discovering Abstractions for Visual Programs from Unstructured Primitives
item.description: Fans of DreamCoder will enjoy, especially those thinking about program synthesis in continuous domains.
item.author: Jones et al., SIGGRAPH 2023

item.title: Feature Guided Search for Creative Problem Solving Through Tool Construction
item.description: Part of a very fun project on "MacGyvering" with a robot (https://ece.gatech.edu/news/2023/12/formula-creativity).
item.author: Nair & Chernova, 2020

item.title: Qualitative Simulation
item.description: This is a classic -- anyone thinking about robots/agents that reason and plan at multiple levels of abstraction, especially in physical systems, will enjoy.
item.author: Kuipers, 1986

item.title: Using Source Code to Solve Control Problems
item.description: If an agent has a programmatic world model, it should use that structure to make better and faster decisions.
item.author: Hernandez Cano, MIT master's thesis, 2024

item.title: Language and Culture Internalisation for Human-Like Autotelic AI
item.description: Makes a very interesting case for social interaction and culture as major drivers for the emergence of intelligent agents.
item.author: Colas et al., Nature MI 2022

item.title: Learning with 3D Rotations, a Hitchhiker's Guide to SO(3)
item.description: This is quickly becoming one of the papers I most often share. Useful, systematic, and nicely written.
item.author: Geist et al., ICML 2024

item.title: Robots for Humanity: In-Home Deployment of Stretch RE2
item.description: This is probably the most inspiring robot video/demo that I've ever seen: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K2U7wwEMLDU
item.author: Ranganeni et al., HRI 2024

item.title: AdaptSim: Task-Driven Simulation Adaptation for Sim-to-Real Transfer
item.description: Simulators need not be realistic---they just need to be useful for downstream decision-making!
item.author: Ren et al., CoRL 2023

item.title: A Survey on Hierarchical Planning â€“ One Abstract Idea, Many Concrete Realizations
item.description: This has the best short intro to Hierarchical Task Networks and related formalisms that I have seen.
item.author: Bercher et al., IJCAI 2019

item.title: REPeat: A Real2Sim2Real Approach for Pre-acquisition of Soft Food Items in Robot-assisted Feeding
item.description: This is the kind of rich, messy manipulation & planning that our robots need.
item.author: Ha*, Ye* et al., IROS 2024

item.title: Uncertainty Quantification for Neurosymbolic Programs via Compositional Conformal Prediction
item.description: Very creative synthesis of ideas. I would love to see applications to robot planning.
item.author: Ramalingam et al., 2024

item.title: Learning Sequential Acquisition Policies for Robot-Assisted Feeding
item.description: I really admire this: it's cool from a general AI/robotics perspective *and* focused on an important application.
item.author: Sundaresan et al., 2023

item.title: Bayesian Policy Search with Policy Priors
item.description: If "learning to learn", "planning as inference", or "hierarchical Bayesian" gets your attention, you'll enjoy this paper. Also, #SnakesOnAPlane.
item.author: Wingate et al., 2011

item.title: Planning for Learning Object Properties
item.description: A very nice instance of using planning to learn (to get better at planning). Real robot results too!
item.author: Lamanna et al., AAAI 2023

item.title: Towards a Unified Theory of State Abstraction for MDPs
item.description: This is my go-to reference for state abstractions. Table 1 is especially helpful.
item.author: Li, Walsh & Littman, 2006

item.title: Semantically Grounded Learning from Unstructured Demonstrations
item.description: A must-read if you're thinking about developing robots that learn (and generalize!) from demonstrations.
item.author: Niekum (Dissertation), 2012

item.title: Learning to Rank for Synthesizing Planning Heuristics
item.description: Heuristics are estimated costs-to-go, so we should train them that way, right? Not necessarily!
item.author: Garrett et al., 2016

item.title: Learning Inadmissible Heuristics During Search
item.description: It's cool and surprising that we can learn to get better at search, during search itself, before even finding a solution.
item.author: Thayer, Dionne & Ruml, 2011

item.title: Learning Tasks From A Single Demonstration
item.description: A title ahead of its time! My favorite part, though, is the thorough & thoughtful discussion section.
item.author: Atkeson & Schaal, 1997

item.title: CORN: Contact-based Object Representation for Nonprehensile Manipulation of General Unseen Objects
item.description: The real nonprehensile manipulation videos are pretty remarkable.
item.author: Cho et al., ICLR 2024

item.title: Inductive Logic Programming At 30: A New Introduction
item.description: When I first started reading about ILP, I really wanted an explanation in modern ML terms. This does that & a lot more!
item.author: Cropper & Dumancic, JAIR 2022

item.title: Learning by Analogy: Formulating and Generalizing Plans from Past Experience
item.description: Ambitious and ahead of its time. Analogical reasoning is under-utilized in modern AI, imo.
item.author: Carbonell, 1982

item.title: Discovery of Complex Behaviors through Contact-Invariant Optimization
item.description: The behaviors synthesized are still among the coolest I've ever seen. An elegant idea, too.
item.author: Mordatch et al., 2012

item.title: Learning Symbolic Models of Stochastic Domains
item.description: This was hugely influential in my PhD. The scope is incredible (you think they're done; then they add concept learning!)
item.author: Pasula, Zettlemoyer, Kaelbling, JAIR 2005

item.title: Finding Options that Minimize Planning Time
item.description: This paper has a unique & compelling answer to the question: how should we discover high-level action abstractions (and why)?
item.author: Jinnai et al., ICML 2019

item.title: Pengi: An Implementation of a Theory of Activity
item.description: This paper points to a kind of improvisational decision-making that I still don't think we've figured out. Also has a great critique of planning.
item.author: Agre & Chapman, 1987
